title: Do you think that there are other life forms exploring the universe aside from humans? - Quora

response.answer_text: QUESTION: Do you think that there are other life forms exploring the universe aside from humans? ANSWER: We can’t know, until we encounter evidence that we recognize. So far, all the direct evidence is negative. No visits. No signals. (Unless you are a conspiracy theorist, in which case, don’t bother reading this.) On the other hand, much of the indirect or circumstantial evidence shows that it is more and more likely that life, and very possibly intelligence, exists. The question is what does “exists” mean. With all the trillions of stars in all the billions of galaxies, and with observational evidence suggesting, not only that most of them have planets, but also that some large percentage is likely to have rocky planets that could be like ours when it began, there’s lots of potential out there. So we are likely talking about billions of planets - maybe even billions in our own galaxy - that have what our planet has - solid surface, comet impacts to bring water ice and hydrocarbons, internal heat, possibly a magnetosphere, a nearby (but not TOO nearby) source of solar energy. Statistically speaking, it would be unlikely that there is not life elsewhere. It would necessarily evolve by natural selection. If intelligence wasn’t some absolute fluke, then there are likely to be other intelligences out there, some of whom must be curious about their place in the cosmos. It’s hard to imagine something truly intelligent that ISN’T curious. The problem is partly WHERE they are, and WHEN they are (er… were…. or are going to be). Look how long it took us to get to the point where we are capable of looking out, finding other worlds (observationally… we can’t visit), and broadcasting our own presence out into the universe. Others, too, must have gone through a period when their worlds exude an expanding bubble of electromagnetic signals that could be distinguishable from non-intelligent sources. But in all the time that there has been a planet Earth (4-billion-ish years?) we’ve been electromagnetically obvious for barely more than 100 years. Before Marconi and friends, we were electromagnetically non-existent to the rest of the universe. Microbes and fishlike creatures and early land-crawlers and dinosaurs and assorted mammals and lizards, and early humans all the way up through the steam age… do not produce any signal that can be detected from another star system. Even if we don’t wise up and get a bit paranoid about announcing ourselves as possible prey, we are still going to become less and less visible if we survive. That’s because blasting out electromagnetic broadcasts costs money. Early radio transmitters and receivers were very inefficient. Shortly after we invented them, we started refining them. The lower the power, the more refined and efficient our communications become, the less unintentional leakage there will be, into outer space. Therefore, as we use “quieter” more efficient, more directional, lower-powered signalling among ourselves, we will naturally become less obvious to outsiders and more difficult to detect against the cosmic background. Similarly, if we destroy ourselves, our little planet will go silent, not long after it found its voice. What does that mean in a universe as vast as this one? Consider just our own Milky Way galaxy if somebody on the farthest opposite side of our local galaxy had sent us a loud radio signal, for us to hear this week, that race of intelligent extra-terrestrials would have needed to launch their transmission 100, 000 years ago. To get a signal to us, from just the other edge of the same galaxy, they would have had to send that signal before there were humans on earth. At the speed of light, that radio transmission would be just getting to us now. Think about electromagnetic waves and the inverse-square law. How weak would it be, after expanding at the speed of light for 100,000 years. If we actually detected it, over/under the enormous radio-frequency noise that is coming from billions of stars, from the super-gigantic black hole at the galaxy’s center, from pulsars and quasars and other high-energy phenomena… and if we then sent a signal back, it would be 200,000 years for them, from original sending to receiving something back. Two hundred thousand years ago, “we” might not even have been quite the species that we are now. Some classifications put the speciation more like 50,000 years ago. But even so, we would have been pre-language, grunting and signing to each other and not even (yet) able to tell each other stories about the lights in the sky. What are the chances that humans will exist ten, twenty, one hundred thousand years from now? What about MUCH nearer to us in the same arm (or a a near one) of this galaxy? What if the most recent nearby civilization was a few hundred light years away? What if that civilization reached its broadcast-radio stage just around the time that Columbus was setting out for North America? They were electronically noisy for a hundred or two-hundred years, and then either annihilated themselves, got caught in an extinction event, or developed their technology to be efficient and quiet, and that brief window of “hey there’s somebody” signalling went whistling past us around the time that “Murrica” was having its revolution. No radios. No radio telescopes. We were still too primitive to notice the neighbors setting off fireworks. Now consider distances between galaxies. Millions and billions of light years. The distance that light can travel in a year… times a million, or times a billion, or ten billion… the numbers are so big that we can’t encompass the time-spans in our minds, never mind the distances. What are the chances we’d be looking in the right direction, with the right equipment, exactly five billion, six hundred million, two hundred and ninety-eight thousand, four hundred and eleven years after somebody “over there in that galaxy” sent a signal big enough and clear enough to be detected here, in 2016 (when I wrote this)? To make an artificial signal stand out from natural sources of radio noise (or gamma-ray noise or whatever frequency was selected as likely to travel furthest and penetrate intervening gas and debris and plasma and…) they would need to have consumed an entire star as a power source. They would also have needed to perform that enormous engineering task (consuming the economies of perhaps hundreds of thriving worlds) that-many billions of years ago, in order for the light-speed wave-front to be arriving at our little world just as we were technologically ready to receive it, and maybe understand what we were receiving. Consider further that the universe is “only” about 14 billion years old, and billions of years ago it was different than it is now. Stars were an earlier generation. Not as many big ones had exploded and seeded the cosmos with heavy elements - the constituents of “life as we know it” or “life as we can imagine it”. So, if a galaxy is currently 4 billion light years away, and a star in that galaxy hosted a planet that had been through four billion years of development, as ours has to produce us, then that planet would be 8 billion years old. That’s more than halfway back to the Big Bang. The dust and gasses that condensed to form that star and its planets could very well have had quite different proportions of elements heavier than the ubiquitous hydrogen. Would that planet have been as conducive to life, after it cooled, as this one was, with all its iron and aluminum and copper and other elements that our lifeforms use? Just sayin’. Anyway, to sum up, my unedjumacated opinion is that there probably are/have-been/will-be many intelligent species out there, but the distances and the timespans make it very chancy that we could detect them, and impossible that we could converse with them. The best that we can do is: a) look b) when we get solidly established in space, construct and leave behind a “memorial” to ourselves that some future civilization might discover. Of course, whether that would inspire awe or fear in them would be another question… after all, if they discover our monument to ourselves, that would immediately raise the question: What killed off the humans, and are we next? The facts of universe-size distance and time, and the fact that we have not detected anybody in the decades that we have been looking/listening suggest that, even if other intelligences are, or have been, “out there”, our chances of being in the right place at the right time and looking with the right equipment is very small indeed. And if they haven’t got to our level yet, then by the time they do and start listening, we will likely be extinct or quiet for other reasons and they won’t detect us. If they send out signals (intentional or not), chances are we will have run our course before that signal ever reaches our world, and the cockroaches that survive us won’t notice or care. Big numbers are awe-inspiring, and they kinda suck.

Pedantry: all other forms of life on Earth are also exploring the universe, albeit in what we think are lesser ways. I’ll assume the question relates to intelligent life outside the solar system. I think yes, but at present that cannot be more than a hunch. There are some necessary steps on the path to intelligent life like ours, about which we have no evidence at all. We now know that most stars have planets. We have no reason to think that there won’t be at least millions if not billions of planets in this galaxy alone, which have liquid water on their surface. Lab experiments have shown that most mixtures of water, methane, and rock, will generate simple organic molecules under the influences of electric discharges (lightning), solar UV, and hot rock (volcanic activity - probably not essential). So the raw ingredients of life will exist elsewhere. We don’t know anything at all about the transition from simple organic chemistry to life. Is it almost inevitable, a one in a billion chance, or so unlikely that in the entire universe it has happened just once? (Here). Likewise, we don’t know anything about the likelyhood of transition from simple life (monocellular, or its unknown, extinct, precursors) to multi-cellular organisms. We do know that here, it took around three billion years for the latter to happen, and that is the greater part of our Sun’s stable lifetime. It’s also a few times longer than the earliest fossil evidence for simple life. There’s “only” a few hundred million years left for future life on Earth (unless our descendants can fix that). Then the sun will have become hotter, enough boil or burn all life on the Earth out of existence. If the sun lasted just one day, we’d have arrived on the scene at about 8pm. If we were a bit lucky getting here by now, that suddenly starts making other arrivals elsewhere before midnight look a lot less likely. (A lot of small red stars live far longer than the sun, but they are also less stable than the sun, and habitable planets would have to be closer, and would end up blasted by flares, or with one side permanently facing the sun like the moon faces the Earth … more unknowns.) We have simply no evidence of life anywhere except here, and one can draw no conclusions at all about the likelyhood of life elsewhere from just one observation thereof. The observation of life elsewhere would change everything, but the observation of life on a planet outside out solar system would be extremely difficult. So it’s just a hunch. Unless the evolution of multi-cellular life is almost inevitable given a planet with surface water and a star that will be stable for a few billion years, we probably never will detect even simple life anywhere else (which tells us nothing). The speed of light is too slow, the distances are too vast. We could be alone in our whole galaxy, and there could still be billions of other intelligences out there, with a small fractional chance of any one galaxy containing just one of them. They’ll all be wondering, as we are, “are we the only intelligent beings in the universe, and can we ever know for sure? “ There’s a reason I think intelligent life is not nearly inevitable on a wet planet, or in pessimistic moments, that intelligent life usually destroys itself. Where are the robot Von Neumann exploration probes? I think it’s probable that organic life cannot ever cross interstellar space. It’s possible to argue against strong AIs or humans uploaded into robot bodies doing so. But if we last as a technological civilisation for more than a few thousand years, surely we’ll work out how to construct a probe that can construct copies of itself out of barren asteroids when it arrives at a nearby star system, some to explore outwards and some to return the observations to us and some to simply remain, saying “we exist”? A simple program, maybe less than that which drives a bacterium, and definitely designed not to mutate. Even if we then went extinct, they’d carry on exploring and leaving that message. They could reach every star in the galaxy in a “mere” few hundred million years. If we aren’t the first in our galaxy, where are the others’ robot exploration missions? This argument could yet change. We’ve not yet explored the Moon and the other rocks without destructive atmospheres and tectonics in enough detail to know that there isn’t a message from the others within our reach.

The universe is a « very » big place. As for what we call life, since we only do know of the phenomenon of self-replicating and growing matter from immediately around us, it is a statistical probability some comparable phenomenons may exist somewhere else around the bazillions of stars we know of. But the universe being so vast, many of the stars we know of are actually dead already, and the means to physically explore the vast emptiness of space are staggeringly challenging. Might there be some other life forms based on silicium instead of carbon ? Or gaseous ? Well, Perhaps. Within the realm of what we know ; we’ve got to acknowledge we know little. Yet one thing we do know : The traveling times between solar systems would be absurdly long within the physics as we know them, and everything else is just pure fantasy. So many forms of « life » may have happened or not in many corners of the observable universe ; but is it VERY unlikely any of them would make it to another one. It’s more likely many of them were exctinct already by the time there were microbian life right here. As for the probability any of us would get to some first contact with even some alien microbian life, again, the odds are terrifyingly short. And in the end ; would we even be able to acknowledge or recognize another form of life as such ? We tend to form categories with what we know already. It’s hard enough to get a clean cut answer whether plants are « sentient » or not ; so would we have any chance at acknowledging the status on some gas-based life at all ? In fine, odds of finding life-forms roughly based on carbon like we are ; that’s almost plausible. That it could have evolved towards something roughly related to animal life as we know it is shaky at best. We’re already very weirded out by many things we discover in the deep oceans.Things that evolved on an altogether different planet would probably be very hard on our little brains. And if they could achieve means of intergalactic travel ? Well we’d probably be unable to fathom the idea much like a bacteria can’t handle the idea of a human being.

It’s a virtual impossibility that there is no other life outside of earth. If there is intelligent, sentient life on the level of humanity or higher is a totally different question. The chances for that seem to be good, however the problem is that we’re dealing with a sample size of one (earth) and we don’t even exactly know how life arose here. I think once we can replicate the conditions and successfully create cellular organisms spontaneously we will then be able to come up with a pretty reliable answer as to how abundant life is in the universe. There’s lot of theories and many attempts to test them however none have ever had any success. Current estimates put the rate of sentient life in the universe at about one per galaxy. Again, that’s made with lots of assumptions that will no doubt change over time. But it sounds like a decent guess to me. I think we would have been visited by aliens already if there were another in our galaxy. With the current age of the universe there could be a civilization about 600 million years older than us right now (we’re at a paltry 250k years), so if intelligent life was extremely abundant then the galaxy sound be teeming with it and we should know of it’s existence. Where will humanity be in 600 million years? It’s doubtful we’d even recognize ourselves physically, let alone mentally and technologically. Of course there’s the possibility that aliens are not contacting us out of some desire to let us grow on our own or that maybe we’re being studied like creatures in a zoo or maybe they’re waiting for us to cross some technological threshold before revealing themselves. Those things seem unlikely to me however since it would only take one rogue alien to screw things up and humanity is getting to the point where we should be able to detect intelligent life, or any life at all, on planets in our galaxy.

Astronomers have been searching out extraterrestrial planets using a variety of telescopes and detection instruments since the late 1990s and now have found thousands with the Kepler space telescope finding about 250 new planets a year for the last 4 years. Most of those discovered so far could not possibly support any kind of life we can imagine but NASA says 7 ‘earth-like’ planets have been found. But we also know that nothing human-like will ever exist on those worlds because ‘earth-like’ is not the ‘like Earth” we have in mind. All we are finding out is that the estimates for the number of planets in our galaxy are probably good estimates which means millions of planets in our own galaxy with billions of galaxies in the visible Universe. So far, the results of the search indicates that maybe one in several thousand planets may be enough like Earth to support at least simple multi-celled creatures. We can therefore confidently say that our galaxy is not teeming with advanced civilizations but may have a few hundred scattered randomly around our galaxy which is 100,000 light years in diameter. None of the ‘nearby’ stars has earth-like planets, either. Which brings up the fact that we and any extraterrestrial civilization live under the same laws of physics. So far, our fastest space craft are unmanned and have only managed to get beyond the orbit of Pluto and into interstellar space after 38 years of constant travel. Getting a space craft directly to Pluto took 10 years, it takes our missions to Mars about 2 years to go that distance. The same approximate ability may be in use by other intelligent beings on other worlds which of course means we won’t be shaking hands with extra terrestrial beings soon or maybe ever. So whatever those unidentified flying objects are, they are not operated by advanced beings touring Earth on vacation.

A new study suggests that there are around 700 quintillion planets in the universe, but only one like Earth. Astrophysicist Erik Zackrisson from Uppsala University in Sweden arrived at this staggering figure — a 7 followed by 20 zeros — with the aid of a computer model that simulated the universe’s evolution following the Big Bang. Zackrisson’s model combined information about known exoplanets with our understanding of the early universe and the laws of physics to recreate the past 13.8 billion years. Zackrisson found that Earth appears to have been dealt a fairly lucky hand. In a galaxy like the Milky Way, for example, most of the planets Zackrisson’s model generated looked very different than Earth — they were larger, older and very unlikely to support life. Zackrisson’s work suggests an alternative to the commonly held assumption that planets similar to Earth must exist, based on the sheer number of planets out there. Astronomers have, to this point, discovered around 30 exoplanets in the habitable zones of stars. Simply extrapolating that figure based on the known number of stars suggests that there should be about 50 billion such planets in the Milky Way alone. Probability seems to dictate that Earth-twins are out there somewhere. But according to Zackrisson, most planets in the universe shouldn’t look like Earth. His model indicates that Earth’s existence presents a mild statistical anomaly in the multiplicity of planets. Most of the worlds predicted by his model exist in galaxies larger than the Milky Way and orbit stars with different compositions — an important factor in determining a planet’s characteristics. His research indicates that, from a purely statistical standpoint, Earth perhaps shouldn’t exist. Source: Earth May Be a 1-in-700-Quintillion Kind of Place - D-brief

With at least 200 billion galaxies out there (and possibly even more), we're very likely talking about a Universe filled with around 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 planets in our observable Universe. Imagine, a 3rd of them have life. Now say a fraction of them have a race of beings that have moved past the planet and started exploring space. Lets say a 6th of all the planets with life. That’s still 1,800,000,000,000,000,000,000 planets that could potentially be exploring space. And this is theorized from what we know that exists now. I would say, without a doubt, that there is something somewhere searching and exploring space right now. I cannot tell you where or how far away they are from us, but they’re there.

Yes. But not within our neighborhood. It took more than 13 Billion years and a billion different species that have come and gone on Earth to finally have ONE species with the ability to explore the Universe. So it takes a helluva long time to cook up life forms with exploring capabilities. And humans nearly didn't make it. We were nearly entirely wiped out by the Toba volcano extinction event. But 13+ billion years for the universe is way way way way too early to start bumping into other planetary civilizations. See the Universe is expected to last about a googol of years. Thats almost like infinity from human time scales. It's more likely we would have advanced across several levels on the Kardashev scale and already populated several planets across our Milky Way or even across nearby galaxies that we might bump into Aliens. But note that most likely, the aliens we meet before that would actually be ourselves. Humans that colonize Mars would become Martians. They would be taller and thinner than earthlings. They need less oxygen and would not survive on Earth without life support. The Earth gravity would incapacitate them too. Every planet or moon colony would evolve to suit that environment, which would have been terraformed but never equal to Earth. That's impossible to ever achieve, an exact environment of Earth.

The question presupposes that there are other technologically advanced beings in the Universe; and that interstellar travel is possible. Firstly, anyone with a decent understanding of biology will testify to the fact that life as we know it is almost unimaginably complex. My personal view is that life as we know it is so improbable that Earth could actually be the only planet in the Universe where there is any life at all; certainly complex life. Then there is the ‘distance problem’. Distances between stars are staggeringly large - even our fastest spacecraft which are leaving the solar system now will take something like seventy thousand years to reach the nearest star; homo sapiens has only existed for about fifty thousand years. At the time of writing, I am not aware that anyone has the foggiest idea how we could realistically undertake journeys to the stars, let alone other galaxies. Best advice is to assume that we are alone, and always will be, and that we won’t be going anywhere soon.

I love that you think we’re exploring the universe. That’s like saying someone on a glass-bottomed boat is exploring the sea. We’re watching the universe and the odds are pretty good that other creatures are doing the same. They probably don’t have the same tools as us. They may be more advanced or they might be three-legged, four-eyed insects. It’s not definitely happening, but there are so many galaxies that it’s statistically likely. There are about 10 to the 24 planets in the universe. That’s a one with twenty four zeroes after it. If only 1% of them are in the Goldilocks zone then that’s billions of possible planets for life to happen on. You can get simple life by just mixing the right chemicals for the right amount of time, under the right conditions. Admittedly they’ve only managed to make very simple single-celled life in a lab, but it can be done. Even if only 1% of the 1% have life then the odds of things that can see the sky existing elsewhere is pretty good. Just don’t expect them to be looking through telescopes :)

Q: Do you believe that there are other life forms exploring the universe? I’ll give you a definite maybe on that. Since humanity exists in a naturalistic universe I see no reason why other civilisations can’t in principle exist, though whether they actually do or not is open to question, at least until we discover them, or they discover us. Maybe we’re far to the right of the Bell Curve and a serious outlier. There’s a paucity of non-insane evidence, which is more strictly speaking testimony, as opposed to evidence, to indicate that ETs exist but it’s not an unreasonable conjecture that they do. But claiming for a fact they do is insane, IMO.

The universe is too large, too huge, and too wide for us to be the only life form to populate it. There is definitely, I have strong feelings about this, that there are life forms wondering about in our observable universe. The real question is; are there any intelligent life forms out there? Here I am on the fence, there might be and there might not be. Looking at how long it took for us to be where we are and the conditions that allowed for us to idle around the milky way I must say that I believe that intelligent life form might be rare in our observable universe. Other people have came up with theories suggesting that there might be silicon based intelligent life form, again I am on the fence here. What I strongly believe in is that there is some other life form, basics life form, in this universe. There are speculations that there are microbes deep inside the ice of Jupiter's icey moon.

Yes, for the same reason Simon gives. Our sample size is admittedly small ( “One” is not a good sample to draw conclusions from) , but we now have detected that many of the stars we see have planets around them. That sampling is evidence of an astronomical (sorry) number of planets where some similar arrangement of circumstances can generate life. That is not necessarily the same as “intelligent” life, but there are again, no rules that say no. So I “believe” that there are other life forms. I suspect there may be others that exist in anoxic environments (because we have some that handle that near the sub-sea vents), there may well be methane breathers out there. We just don’t know because we can’t go look. Yet.

Yes, and that is only for Life as we know it. The universe is so incredibly huge that thinking we are the only ones alive in this is almost absurd. There have been recent discoveries of stars with planetary systems like ours. Even with planets we like to categorize as in the goldilocks zone. This means we are looking for recognizable life in those planets so we can somehow relate and possibly colonize. Climate change will be the least of the worries there i guess. Looking for signs of life as we know it may be a handicap. What if alien lifeform is unrecognizable? If those happen to be beyond our visual or auditory wavelength that our instruments can detect, then they would be right under our noses and we’ll be clueless about it. Living organisms outside our planet will definitely be very different from what we are used to. It will not be carbon-based and definitely not like those in the movies. Then there is intelligence. What if this is a very unique trait?

I do not ‘believe’ things. I understand the causality and possibilities depending on that causality. There is no knowledge that can lead us to know that there was/is/will be life elsewhere in the universe (exploring it like we do, or not), yet. As we know what the requirements are for life, as we know it here on Earth, recognizing that these settings aren’t unique per se (we have found several planets in situations equal to ours, and we only are looking since the last 100 years and less). Thus we have to acknowledge it is very likely that there are other locations where life has evolved/is evolving/will evolve, around the universe. Do I have good understanding that it is very likely that there are other life forms in the universe, other than from/on Earth? Yes.

Q.Do you think that there are other life forms exploring the universe aside from humans? I can only answer for The DAVIES Hypothesis - YouTube (The DAVIES Hypothesis - YouTube). The odds of life emerging from inanimate compounds are billions and billions to one. Fortunately, there are billions and billions of planets orbiting billions of stars in our observed universe making the odds reasonable. However, I contend that our (dual) universe is one of a near infinite number expanding, impinging and coalescing making unimaginably old and huge universes in which the chances of life emerging tantamount to certainty. All these universes obey the same laws of physics but evolutionary constraints might result in different life forms emerging although conscious life will emerge. Panspermia allows ‘living’ entities to move throughout universes.

I believe there are other lifeforms in the Universe because there are lifeforms here, there is no law of physics preventing it, and the laws of biology and chemistry pretty much mean that if it is possible for life to appear in a place, then life will almost certainly appear in that place. Mind you, this is a tentative belief: direct evidence of life elsewhere is scarce to non-existent. Discovering signs of life on other Worlds (ie Mars or Europa), or failing to find them, would help us better understand how life arose on the Earth. #grammarnazi : you mean “are”, in there, not “is”.

Have you ever heard of a dog? A fish? A deer? An elephant? There are plenty. I’m going to assume that you mean other INTELLIGENT life forms. The answer is almost definitely a yes, but we don’t know about them. There are millions if not billions of planets in our galaxy, and there are millions if not billions of galaxies. The odds that our little ball of dirt and water is the only one in existence that evolved intelligent life is so unlikely, so implausible, that I’m willing to call it impossible.

Do you think there are other life-forms exploring the universe aside from humans? I think, statistically, there are many other life-forms in the universe doing just that, based on the sheer scale and numbers of stars and galaxies that we know to exist. On that basis I see no compelling argument for human exceptionalism.
